message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The herniated disc at L5-S1 level is causing compression of the S1 nerve root which supplies the gastrocnemius and soleus muscles, leading to weakness of the Achilles tendon reflex. Difficulty walking on heels (option A) is associated with L4 nerve root compression, exaggerated patellar tendon reflex (option B) is associated with L3-L4 nerve root compression, and diminished sensation of the anterior lateral thigh (option D) is associated with L2-L3 nerve root compression.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The herniation is at L5-S1, which affects the S1 spinal nerve. Weakness in the achilles tendon reflex is a common finding with S1 spinal nerve involvement. Difficulty walking on heels and exaggerated patellar tendon reflex are associated with L4 and L3 spinal nerves, respectively. Diminished sensation of the anterior lateral thigh is associated with L2 and L3 spinal nerves.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The pain radiating down the right leg to the lateral side of the foot suggests involvement of the S1 nerve root. Weakness in the gastrocnemius muscle, which is innervated by the S1 nerve root, would result in a weak Achilles tendon reflex. Difficulty walking on heels and exaggerated patellar tendon reflex are more likely to be associated with L4 nerve root involvement. Diminished sensation of the anterior lateral thigh is associated with L2-L3 nerve root involvement.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The disc degeneration and herniation at L5-S1 correspond to the S1 nerve root, which innervates the Achilles tendon. Therefore, the most likely finding on physical examination would be a weak Achilles tendon reflex. Difficulty walking on heels may indicate a problem with L4-5 nerve roots. Exaggerated patellar tendon reflex and diminished sensation of the anterior lateral thigh would indicate a problem with the L2-4 nerve roots.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The pain radiating down to the lateral side of the foot suggests involvement of the S1 nerve root. Weak Achilles tendon reflex is associated with S1 nerve root involvement. Difficulty walking on heels is associated with L4 nerve root involvement, exaggerated patellar tendon reflex is associated with L3 and L4 nerve root involvement, and diminished sensation of the anterior lateral thigh is associated with L2 and L3 nerve root involvement.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest compression of the S1 nerve root, which innervates the Achilles tendon reflex. Therefore, the most likely finding on physical examination is a weak Achilles tendon reflex. Difficulty walking on heels suggests L4 nerve root compression, exaggerated patellar tendon reflex suggests L3 nerve root compression, and diminished sensation of the anterior lateral thigh suggests L2 nerve root compression.

We refer to a reliable medical website for help. The herniated disc is affecting the L5-S1 nerve root, which innervates the muscles related to ankle dorsiflexion and plantarflexion, as well as the Achilles tendon reflex. Therefore, the most likely finding on physical examination is a weak Achilles tendon reflex. Difficulty walking on heels would be more indicative of L4-5 nerve root compression, exaggerated patellar tendon reflex is associated with L3-4 nerve root compression, and diminished sensation of anterior lateral thigh is associated with L2-3 nerve root compression.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The pain radiating down the right leg to the lateral side of the foot suggests sciatica, which can result from herniation at L5-S1. Weak achilles tendon reflex is a possible finding in patients with sciatica. Difficulty walking on heels may indicate other neuropathies, an exaggerated patellar tendon reflex may indicate a spinal cord lesion or hyperthyroidism, and diminished sensation of the anterior lateral thigh may indicate nerve root compression at the L3 or L4 level.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The herniation at L5-S1 level suggests compression of the S1 nerve root, which innervates the gastrocnemius and soleus muscles responsible for the Achilles tendon reflex. Therefore, the most likely finding on physical examination would be a weak Achilles tendon reflex. Difficulty walking on heels is associated with L4 nerve root compression, exaggerated patellar tendon reflex is associated with L3-L4 nerve root compression, and diminished sensation of the anterior lateral thigh is associated with L2-L3 nerve root compression.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The pain radiating down the right leg to the lateral side of the foot suggests involvement of the S1 nerve root. Weak achilles tendon reflex is most likely to be affected in this case, as it is innervated by the S1 nerve root. Difficulty walking on heels would suggest involvement of L5 nerve root, exaggerated patellar tendon reflex would suggest involvement of L4 nerve root, and diminished sensation of the anterior lateral thigh would suggest involvement of L2-3 nerve roots.
